Key Arguments: Concerns about who decides what information is false, misleading, or deceptive.
Fact-checking is subjective and potentially biased due to financial incentives.
The definition of 'false, misleading or deceptive' information is vague and open to misuse.
Exclusion of government and professional news sources from misinformation scrutiny is problematic, as they have been sources of misinformation in the past.
The legislation undermines freedom of expression as outlined in international human rights agreements.
Main Themes: Vagueness and potential misuse of definitions
Notable Quotes: META has already acknowledged in court that factcheck is opinion, and RMIT factlab are paid $800 per fact check.
The exclusion and the ‘parody' don't inspire confidence or trust.
Please respect my ‘freedom of expression; this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers...'
